issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires a method named checkOrderReady() (UML and task descriptions) that is called from orderMeal() to attempt serving queued orders. The reference solution implements this behavior in a method named processOrders() instead of checkOrderReady(). This name/signature mismatch between the specification and the solution can confuse students about the exact API they must implement (and may break tests or grading that expect checkOrderReady()).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the specification: provide a public method named checkOrderReady() that implements (or delegates to) the current processOrders() logic and ensure orderMeal() calls checkOrderReady(). Alternatively, rename processOrders() to checkOrderReady() so the method name in the solution matches the problem statement and tests.

issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires a method named checkOrderReady() (used to attempt to serve queued orders). In the reference solution the same behavior is implemented in a method named processOrders(). This naming mismatch (checkOrderReady vs. processOrders) creates a conceptual mapping barrier: students reading the problem expect/implement checkOrderReady(), but the solution uses a different identifier, which can confuse students and cause mismatch with tests or instructor references.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the solution method processOrders() to checkOrderReady(), or add a public checkOrderReady() wrapper that delegates to processOrders(). Ensure the method signature is public void checkOrderReady() so names in the problem statement, template expectations, and solution match and students can map requirements to implementation unambiguously.
